quotes.topic_title: Customer obsession and working backwards framing
quotes.text: ... Jeff would say, we took it as an article of faith.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Captures the foundational belief that guides Amazon’s decision-making approach.

quotes.topic_title: Customer obsession and working backwards framing
quotes.text: If we served customers well, if we prioritized customers and delivered for them, things like sales, things like revenue and active customers and things like the share price and free cash flow would follow.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A clear causal model: customer outcomes first, business metrics follow as downstream effects.

quotes.topic_title: Customer obsession and working backwards framing
quotes.text: So therefore, when we're making a decision thinking about a problem, we're going to start with what's best for the customer and then come backward from there.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Actionable decision rule that operationalizes customer obsession via “working backwards.”

quotes.topic_title: Customer obsession and working backwards framing
quotes.text: That informs what's the work you have to do to then create this new solution for customers.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Shows how the method translates from principle into concrete planning and execution steps.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we go many levels deep on how to actually implement a number of the practices and ways of working that helped Amazon become the success that it is today, including the process of how to actually work backwards, how to organize your team with a single-threaded leader, how to divide up your metrics into input and output metrics, how to practice disagreeing and committing, how to implement the Bar Raiser program in your hiring process and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A dense preview of multiple actionable Amazon operating mechanisms (working backwards, single-threaded leadership, input/output metrics, disagree-and-commit, Bar Raiser hiring).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Bill joined Amazon just five years after it was founded, stayed there for 15 years where he worked on the books business, and then as VP of Digital Media, launched and managed the company's global digital music and video businesses, including Amazon Music, Prime Video, and Amazon Studios.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes Bill’s firsthand experience scaling multiple major Amazon businesses, grounding the practices discussed in real operating history.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Bill runs a consulting firm called Working Backwards, LLC, where he and his co-authored, Colin Breyer, help growth stage and public companies implement the many practices developed at Amazon.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights that these Amazon practices are positioned as implementable playbooks for other companies, not just Amazon-specific lore.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The one that's non-obvious and is really the way in which Amazon created a set of leadership principles that were very real, and the way in which Amazon created a set of processes to reinforce them.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Highlights a replicable operating-system idea: define real principles and back them with reinforcing mechanisms, not posters.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But what people don't realize is that Amazon was actually, to some degree, equally focused on process innovation.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Counterbalances the usual product-innovation narrative and points practitioners to invest deliberately in process as a competitive advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And again, that's also why we wrote the book was because we would like to allow people to stand on Amazon's shoulders to learn what we learned, and then take all or part of these things and build from there.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Actionable permissioning: adopt proven mechanisms selectively and iterate rather than copying wholesale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So, this period of both product and process innovation actually occurred in this one narrow window of 2003 to 2007.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A concrete data point suggesting that major operating-model breakthroughs can cluster during specific scaling transitions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So, I'm going to experiment, like a scientist would, with different ideas, different hypotheses, implement them and see what works, and iteratively improve.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A practical methodology for scaling: treat company-building (process and product) as iterative experimentation with hypotheses and feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Amazon’s distinctive processes and leadership principles
quotes.text: The one that's non-obvious and is really the way in which Amazon created a set of leadership principles that were very real, and the way in which Amazon created a set of processes to reinforce them.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Highlights a less-discussed Amazon mechanism: making leadership principles “real” by embedding them in reinforcing processes.

quotes.topic_title: Amazon’s distinctive processes and leadership principles
quotes.text: I think I certainly haven't encountered anything quite like that.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Emphasizes the uniqueness of Amazon’s approach to operationalizing leadership principles, suggesting it’s a differentiator worth studying.

quotes.topic_title: Amazon’s distinctive processes and leadership principles
quotes.text: It was very intentional.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Underscores that Amazon’s culture mechanisms didn’t emerge accidentally—they were deliberately designed, implying practitioners should design theirs too.

quotes.topic_title: Amazon’s distinctive processes and leadership principles
quotes.text: there are companies that are bigger than Amazon, that are more successful than Amazon, that have been around longer than Amazon, but I don't think any other company has contributed so many unique, new ways of working and also been able to coin them into such shareable ways.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames the core puzzle: Amazon’s outsized influence on management practices despite not being the biggest/oldest, pointing to replicable “shareable mechanisms.”

quotes.topic_title: Why Amazon innovated in process and product
quotes.text: But what people don't realize is that Amazon was actually, to some degree, equally focused on process innovation.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Highlights the often-missed idea that scaling innovation requires innovating in management/process, not just products.

quotes.topic_title: Why Amazon innovated in process and product
quotes.text: And again, that's also why we wrote the book was because we would like to allow people to stand on Amazon's shoulders to learn what we learned, and then take all or part of these things and build from there.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Actionable encouragement to adopt and adapt proven mechanisms rather than reinventing everything from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: Why Amazon innovated in process and product
quotes.text: So, this period of both product and process innovation actually occurred in this one narrow window of 2003 to 2007.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A specific data point showing that major innovation can cluster during a scaling inflection period.

quotes.topic_title: Why Amazon innovated in process and product
quotes.text: And you need a system, a method to run the company effectively.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A concise scaling lesson: complexity forces a shift from founder-driven management to explicit operating mechanisms.

quotes.topic_title: Why Amazon innovated in process and product
quotes.text: So, I'm going to experiment, like a scientist would, with different ideas, different hypotheses, implement them and see what works, and iteratively improve.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A reusable methodology for building management mechanisms via hypothesis-driven experimentation and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: A failed mechanism: the “fitness function” metric
quotes.text: So, we're going to create something called a fitness function, which was let's figure out what are the four or five or six metrics that matter most for your particular area. Let's give a weighting to all of them and then let's create an index for those, and we'll measure that index up and down. And that's the fitness function.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Introduces Amazon’s (ultimately abandoned) framework for combining multiple key metrics into a single weighted index.

quotes.topic_title: A failed mechanism: the “fitness function” metric
quotes.text: This is what I would describe as a compound metric where you try to take several important metrics and munge them into one. The problem is it's actually becomes totally meaningless.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A blunt warning that composite metrics can destroy clarity rather than improve measurement.

quotes.topic_title: A failed mechanism: the “fitness function” metric
quotes.text: When you're measuring things, you're trying to understand what actions or reactions are creating the good outputs that you want, revenue, customer growth. But by putting them all together, you basically obfuscate that.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Explains the causal reasoning failure: bundling metrics makes it harder to learn what’s actually driving outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: A failed mechanism: the “fitness function” metric
quotes.text: And what really we realized is we need to just break each one of these out individually and manage them each in its own way. So today, I discouraged teams and companies from creating any sort of compound metrics.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: manage key metrics separately and avoid compound indices.

quotes.topic_title: A failed mechanism: the “fitness function” metric
quotes.text: I've done that once, and it was a terrible idea as well, where we had six different metrics and every quarter, we were going to move a different metric that contributed to a higher metric. And what we realized is we just never learn how to get good at one thing, and then it turns out there's always one thing that actually impacts the bigger goal most. See, you just end up working on that thing anyway.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of how rotating focus across multiple metrics prevents mastery and usually collapses to the single highest-leverage driver.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded leaders: purpose and structure
quotes.text: So, what we realized instead was how do we get... The three things we really wanted were ownership, speed and agility.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Defines the core outcomes single-threaded leadership is designed to optimize for, giving practitioners a clear target to design around.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded leaders: purpose and structure
quotes.text: Let's create teams that can stand alone, where there's a single leader and the cross- functional resources that they need are all either directly report to them or are dedicated to them.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A concrete structural prescription for reducing dependency and increasing accountability in cross-functional work.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded leaders: purpose and structure
quotes.text: But fundamentally, we've moved from what we called a project orientation to a program orientation.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model shift (projects → programs) that changes how teams are staffed, measured, and prioritized.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded leaders: purpose and structure
quotes.text: So, it also solves a big management problem, which is instead of management, senior management refereeing every item on a roadmap, they're refereeing which teams have how many resources, which is more of like a once or twice or three times a year decision versus refereeing everything on the product roadmap.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Actionable reframing of leadership work: allocate resources periodically rather than adjudicating day-to-day roadmap decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded leaders: purpose and structure
quotes.text: In this case, you're trading off potentially functional excellence.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that this org design has real downsides, prompting teams to plan explicit countermeasures.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability with reviews; GM model comparison
quotes.text: There was an intense review process at Amazon where either at some level, whether it be the vice president, senior vice president, or all the way up to the Jeff level and his direct reports called the S-Team, this plan would be reviewed and scrutinized deeply as well, and there'd be a discussion, an interchange, and basically getting alignment between the senior leadership team and each one of these single-threaded teams on that plan before the team could go off and run.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Clarifies the operating model: single-threaded ownership still requires rigorous senior alignment before execution autonomy.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability with reviews; GM model comparison
quotes.text: The beauty of that though is that once we'd had those discussions, those interchanges, then the teams were free to sprint hard after their plan.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Actionable principle: invest upfront in alignment to unlock faster, uninterrupted execution later.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability with reviews; GM model comparison
quotes.text: I've seen many CEO pull their hair out saying, "I have no ownership and accountability here. How do I have that?" They're pushing on a string.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Memorable diagnosis of matrixed/cross-functional ambiguity: without a clear owner, leadership can’t effectively drive outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability with reviews; GM model comparison
quotes.text: Because they can't because their different people and leaders are part owning, half owning a long list of things instead of fully owning a short list of things.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Concrete mental model for accountability: prefer full ownership of fewer priorities over partial ownership of many.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability with reviews; GM model comparison
quotes.text: But you have to be thoughtful about how you do this because one of the three questions you have to ask when you establish one of these teams is, does the team have the resources within their control to effectively manage this part of this department, this product, this P&L?
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Practical test for org design: don’t create a GM/single-threaded unit unless it controls the resources needed to deliver.

quotes.topic_title: Countermeasures for functional excellence in teams
quotes.text: So, what we did, and I'll stick with the engineering examples, we came up with various countermeasures.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Introduces the idea that cross-functional/generalist leadership requires explicit mechanisms to preserve functional excellence.

quotes.topic_title: Countermeasures for functional excellence in teams
quotes.text: One example was that we still had a C-level leader of engineering in Rick Dalzell, and most of the core infrastructure and core services still reported into Rick.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Highlights a structural countermeasure: keep strong functional leadership and centralized ownership of core services even with single-threaded teams.

quotes.topic_title: Countermeasures for functional excellence in teams
quotes.text: Rick still could be a technical leader for the whole company and he and his team could create things like what are the standard ways that we're going to do code reviews? What are the standard ways across the company that we will interview and screen engineers? What does the promotion process look like? What are the defined steps getting from an SD1 to an SD2, SD3? How do we document and describe what are the requirements?
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable playbook for maintaining functional quality via standardized practices (reviews, hiring, promotions, leveling).

quotes.topic_title: Countermeasures for functional excellence in teams
quotes.text: Effectively, what it also meant is that anyone who is an engineering vice president, or in many cases a director, they would often have something else beyond their day job of some sort of subject matter expertise area where they would also contribute to the company.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Describes an operating model where senior leaders carry an explicit second mandate to uphold functional excellence across the org.

quotes.topic_title: Countermeasures for functional excellence in teams
quotes.text: A good example of this would be that they might sit on a panel for promotion from a certain level to another level in the engineering world, or they might be available to do code review outside of their organization for another organization.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Provides specific mechanisms (cross-org promotion panels and external code reviews) that teams can implement to prevent functional drift.

quotes.topic_title: Disagree and commit: meaning and correct use
quotes.text: What it means is that have backbone and disagree, meaning when we are making any kind of a decision, important decision, if you are part of that team, part of that unit, it is your obligation to voice your point of view if you disagree with your approach that's been taken.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Clarifies that dissent isn’t optional—it’s a responsibility during decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Disagree and commit: meaning and correct use
quotes.text: The point of that disagreement, by the way, is to provide usually additional information or a new point of view that people have not considered.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Reframes disagreement as an information-sharing mechanism, not conflict or politics.

quotes.topic_title: Disagree and commit: meaning and correct use
quotes.text: Now that is the point at which as long as the disagreer is hearing back from the leader that they understand their point of view, understand why they are pushing back and seem to fully understand it, and they've taken that into consideration, that is the point for them to commit.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Defines the “handoff” moment from debate to alignment: commit once you’ve been understood and weighed.

quotes.topic_title: Disagree and commit: meaning and correct use
quotes.text: Because the worst thing to do is to say, "Yeah, we're committed to this. I don't really agree and I still think it's wrong, but I'm committed to it." That's not actually commitment.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Challenges the common misconception that compliance equals commitment, warning against passive resistance.

quotes.topic_title: Disagree and commit: meaning and correct use
quotes.text: You have to look for what that is, and then your job is to then take that kernel and try to run with it and expand it and try to see how I can take that idea, that concept, and then make it into something viable.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Offers a practical method for committing even when you still disagree: find the “kernel” and make it workable.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders are right a lot: judgment and experience
quotes.text: So the data rarely makes the decision for you.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive reality: decisions usually require judgment beyond what the data alone can dictate.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders are right a lot: judgment and experience
quotes.text: What is happening is then a lot of judgment and interpretation of the data, weighing that, weighing various factors to then come to a decision.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Offers a practical decision-making framework: interpret data and explicitly weigh multiple factors rather than expecting a single metric to decide.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders are right a lot: judgment and experience
quotes.text: A lot of experiences actually about being wrong, by the way, about making mistakes and by having looked at a lot of problems, made decisions or observed others making decisions, being a student of that, and then using that to understand then how to weight different information when making a decision.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on building judgment: learn from mistakes and systematically study decisions to improve how you weight inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders are right a lot: judgment and experience
quotes.text: No one is right every time. That is totally unrealistic.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Reframes the bar for leadership judgment as probabilistic (“right a lot”) rather than perfection, which is more realistic and sustainable.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: definition and customer-first logic
quotes.text: They both refer to the same idea, which is that as your guiding star or the point from which you're going to start is what are the customer's problems or what are the customer's needs, and then figure out, okay, well what would be the solution to that, what are potential solutions to that?
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Defines the core “working backwards” framework: start from customer needs as the guiding star, then derive solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: definition and customer-first logic
quotes.text: To do those things, starting with without the constraints of my financial constraints, my resource constraints, my legal constraints, my engineering constraints, whatever all those constraints may be, because the problem is what most of us do is we start with those constraints and work forward from there, or we start with things like I got to increase revenue.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance to begin ideation without typical constraints (and not from revenue targets) to avoid being led in the wrong direction.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: definition and customer-first logic
quotes.text: Whereas we had, as Jeff would say, we took it as an article of faith. If we served customers well, if we prioritized customers and delivered for them, we took it as an article of faith that then things like sales, things like revenue and active customers and things like the share price and free cash flow would follow.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: treat customer value as the primary input and assume business outcomes follow.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: definition and customer-first logic
quotes.text: So therefore, when we're making a decision thinking about a problem, we're going to start with what's best for the customer and then come backward from there. Then in that coming backward process, we're going to have to figure out, well, to do that, gee, I'm going to have to solve this engineering problem, or I'm going to have to figure out how to make this thing cost less or make this thing faster or solve one or more problems.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Actionable decision process: pick the customer-best outcome first, then enumerate the engineering/cost/speed problems to solve to make it real.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: definition and customer-first logic
quotes.text: Because in itself, driving down costs, doing things more efficiently doesn't inherently benefit customers because you could just choose to take more profit. It only does if you decide that in doing so I'm going to lower my prices to customers or provide some other benefit.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Clarifies that internal efficiency is not customer value unless explicitly translated into customer-facing benefits (e.g., lower prices).

quotes.topic_title: Implementing PR/FAQ: press release, iteration, funnel
quotes.text: So what I work first is to say, okay, for your product development process, let's start by using this method as the method to decide what am I going to go build? And oh, by the way, to use it as a method to sort between a lot of different choices of what you might build.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Positions PR/FAQ not as documentation, but as a decision-making and prioritization mechanism for what to build.

quotes.topic_title: Implementing PR/FAQ: press release, iteration, funnel
quotes.text: In summary, the way that process works is that PR, you're going to describe very carefully and clearly who's the customer, what's their problem, and what's the solution that you're planning to build. That sounds really simple and easy, but it's actually very hard to do that well. to crisply and clearly define those.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Defines the core PR/FAQ structure and highlights the real difficulty: crisp specificity on customer and problem.

quotes.topic_title: Implementing PR/FAQ: press release, iteration, funnel
quotes.text: Because there's this iterative nature to writing PR/FAQs where it's sort of a concentric circle review. You start off small with one author and with low fidelity writing these things, and then you start to share them with a small group and get feedback and improve it, a wider group, get feedback and improve it, and onward and onward until, depending on the size and scale of your company, you get up to the CEO as a way to strengthen, improve and really codify this idea and determine whether it's a great idea or not.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Introduces the “concentric circle review” as an iterative mechanism to pressure-test and strengthen ideas before committing resources.

quotes.topic_title: Implementing PR/FAQ: press release, iteration, funnel
quotes.text: The date is also a meaningful thing when you write the press release. The date is meant to be a hypothetical timing on which you're envisioning launching this thing which tells the reader something. Are you thinking that this is something that's so simple and easy, we're going to launch it next month or so complex that we're going to launch it in a year from now.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: Shows how even “press release artifacts” (like a launch date) function as cues that force clarity on scope and complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Implementing PR/FAQ: press release, iteration, funnel
quotes.text: The point is not every single one of them is destined to go that far. The numbers get narrower. And this leads me down to the concept of what you're really trying to create is a product funnel, not a product tunnel.
quotes.speaker: Bill Carr
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that the process should intentionally filter out ideas—most should die early—creating a funnel rather than pushing everything through.
